Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: System for Automatic Analysis of Surgical Skills
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, based on research in the areas of robotics and intelligent systems, involves automated techniques for evaluating surgical skills.

Routine evaluation of basic surgical skills in medical schools require considerable time and effort from the supervising faculty. For each surgical trainee, a supervisor has to observe the trainees in person or look at recorded videos. This manual assessment of surgical skills poses a significant resource problem to medical schools and teaching hospitals and results in complications in scheduling/executing their day-to-day activities. In addition to the extensive time requirements, manual assessments are often subjective and domain experts do not always agree on the assessment scores. Every surgical resident has to master basic suturing and knot tying tasks before they can move on to more complex surgeries. Considering the burden on supervising surgery faculty from performing actual surgeries and the amount of trainees that need to go through basic surgical skills training, a system for automated assessment of basic surgical tasks can benefit medical schools and teaching hospitals.

The project addresses the potential commercialization of a system for automated assessment of basic surgical skills. The system consists of a central station with user interface and specialized instruments and gloves for the user. Data about movement of the gloves and instruments are captured using accelerometers and transmitted wirelessly to the central station. Using machine learning, the data will be processed and compared to the performance of a skilled surgeon on the same task. Based on that analysis, a score on the surgical skill will be displayed for the user. The users will be able to keep track of their previously obtained scores, which will allow them to see their progress over time. This will also be beneficial for the supervising surgeon who can monitor trainees' skill improvement before allowing them to move on to more complex procedures. Having such a system available in teaching hospitals and medical schools could help teaching surgeons save valuable time that they could spend doing more surgeries and also give students more opportunities for valuable feedback. This could result in a higher patient throughput for hospitals and improve the overall healthcare system. Through NSF I-Corps, the team will conduct interviews with expert surgeons and residents from different teaching hospitals to validate the need for an automated system for grading. Moreover, the team will also conduct interviews with people in dentistry to see if the proposed technology can be used in their domain as well. The team also plans to interview administrators of medical schools and teaching hospitals to understand their process for evaluating and purchasing training aids.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Goals and Summary of Effort:

Timely evaluation and feedback is an essential part of surgical training. In medical schools, a supervising surgeon who observes a trainee surgeon performing a procedure traditionally assesses surgical skills manually. Although supervision is necessary for resident training, manual evaluation and observing each individual trainee is time-consuming and subjective. Structured manual grading systems, such as the Objective Structured Assessment of Technical Skills (OSATS) are used in medical schools to alleviate the problem of subjectivity in manual assessments. However, manual assessment of each trainee surgeon on a variety of OSATS criteria is still time-consuming besides being inherently subjective.

Every surgical resident, during the course of their residency, has to master basic suturing and knot tying skills before moving on to more complicated procedures. Since the residents need feedback from expert surgeons who are generally very busy, the efficiency of the training phase of the residents reduces significantly. Keeping this in mind, an automated system for the assessment of basic surgical skills can be of a huge benefit to the medical schools and teaching hospitals. 

Our research team at Georgia Tech has developed a tool for surgical skills assessment using video and accelerometer data gives sufficient proof that basic surgical tasks can be assessed automatically with high accuracy given sufficient prior data. This can allow us to design specialized gloves and surgical instruments which can assess the skill of the surgical resident performing the basic surgical task.

The specific goal of this I-Corps effort was to explore commercialization of this assessment system. A detailed analysis of the business plan for this tool was conducted under the guise of Dexteriat Inc. Our basic hypothesis was that "Students and residents pursuing surgical specialties will use (buy) our specialized surgical gloves and instruments to gain feedback while improving their surgical skills." To access this business plan, we undertook 84 interviews and explored a variety of business propositions. In final analysis, it was felt that while there is a need for such a tool, the surgical training programs to date are seeking more advanced training of more complicated procedures then our system can provide. To that end, it was decided to pursue more advanced techniques based on the feedback garnered. 

Intellectual Merits: 

The intellectual merits of this effort were in how computer vision, machine learning, and ubiquitous computing techniques were employed to develop a stand-alone system and in this I-Corp effort, we took the effort to understand the commercial viability of such system with medical experts, and took an evidence-based analysis to verify both the business and technical needs of this product. 

Broader Impacts:

The long-term impact envisioned for this effort was a tool to aid in surgical training, There are currently more than 1000 teaching hospitals and around 150 medical schools in the US alone. And, our interviews with domain experts revealed that there is indeed a significant need for this kind of a tool. In the long run, we learned that we have to continue developing this tool for more complex training tasks.
